title: Manchester City look set to build on their global expansion as they move a step closer to buying a club in Uruguay
text:

Manchester City are hoping to strike a deal to buy a club in Uruguay as they look to expand their growing number of foreign teams. 
City Football Group have identified South America as their next target and are hoping that a partner club will help them with commercial growth. 
They already own New York City, Melbourne City and Yokohama Marinos and are now looking at the next stage in their global expansion. City Football Group are hoping to enter the South American market (Photo: Alex Livesey) 
According to the Daily Mail, club chiefs are also looking at ownership of a Chinese Club, but are prioritising acquisition of a Uruguayan partner. 
City are confident that a move into the South American market will help with the signing of top quality players from that area. 
The former Premier League champions had problems in securing the £27million signing of Gabriel Jesus from Palmeiras after the move was held up for weeks owing to a third-party ownership claim involving the striker’s former agent. City had issues when they signed Gabriel Jesus (Photo: Manchester City FC/Press Association) 
Having a partner in that region could avoid a similar situation taking place as City look to secure the best talent without any issues. 
Reports suggest that other Premier League club are considering a similar acquisition in South America and have sent officials to Brazil and Colombia.
